title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: Thanks checking rPHG! document, go functionalities used work practical haplotype graph (PHG) API via R. PHG trellis graph based representation genic intergenic regions (called reference ranges reference intervals) represent diversity across taxa. can used : create custom genomes alignment, call rare alleles, impute genotypes, efficiently store genomic data many lines (.e. reference, assemblies, lines). Skim sequences generated given taxon aligned consensus sequences PHG identify haplotype node given anchor. anchors given taxon processed Hidden Markov Model (HMM) identify likely path graph. Path information used identify variants (SNPs). Low cost sequencing technologies, coupled PHG, facilitate genotyping large number samples increase size training populations genomic selection models. can turn increase predictive accuracy selection intensity breeding program. Detailed documentation source code can found website: https://bitbucket.org/bucklerlab/practicalhaplotypegraph/wiki/Home

title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: main goal developing package construct R-based front-end build interact PHG API implements commonly used Biocondcutor classes, data structures, accessor methods downstream analysis integration packages.

title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: Since PHG written Java, Java JDK need installed machine. Additionally, R communicate Java, R package rJava need installed. Detailed information can found using following links, depending OS: Linux macOS Windows

what: Problems with rJava if you have upgraded Java
title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: using macOS, previously rJava working RStudio, upgraded Java now longer works, try following: command line type: check left symbolic link via: link exists, remove , create fresh via commands: now able enter RStudio setup rJava.
code: R CMD javareconf ls -ltr /usr/local/lib/libjvm.dylib rm /usr/local/lib/libjvm.dylib sudo ln -s $(/usr/libexec/java_home)/lib/server/libjvm.dylib /usr/local/lib

title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: rJava running machine, install rPHG installing source code BitBucket repository: source code compiled, package can loaded using: , want use function without violating environment can use rPHG::<function>, <function> rPHG function.
code: if (!require("devtools")) install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_bitbucket(     repo = "bucklerlab/rphg",     ref = "master",     build_vignettes = TRUE ) library(rPHG)

previous_headings: Installation and Preliminary Steps > Preliminary steps
title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: Since genome-wide association analyses can use lot computational resources, memory allocation rPHG can modified. change amount memory, use base options() function modify following parameter: Replace <memory> specified unit memory. example, want allocate maximum 6 GB memory operations, use input "-Xmx6g", g stands gigabyte (GB). information memory allocation can found . NOTE: Setting Java memory options rPHG rJava-related packages needs set loading rPHG package!
code: options(java.parameters = c("-Xmx<memory>", "-Xms<memory>"))

previous_headings: Installation and Preliminary Steps > Preliminary steps
what: The importance of logging your progress
title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: begin analyzing data, optional parameters can set make rPHG efficient. prevent R console overloaded PHG logging information, highly recommended start logging file. file house PHG’s logging output beneficial debugging tracking progress analytical workflow. start logging file, use following command: rPHG::startLogger() parameters set NULL, logging file created current working directory. unsure working directory R, use base getwd() command. Additionally, since general walkthrough, certain intricacies function may glossed . like study function full, refer R documentation using ?<function> console, <function> rPHG-based function.
code: rPHG::startLogger(fullPath = NULL, fileName = NULL)

title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: idea behind PHG given breeding program, parental genotypes can sequenced high coverage, loaded parental haplotypes relational database. Progeny can sequenced low coverage used infer parental haplotypes/genotypes database likely present given progeny.

title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: Currently, PHG can use SQLite PostgreSQL store data pan-genomic graph. information data stored within database schema, please refer wiki.

title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: Access PHG database, regardless database type, requires configuration file. file contains various metadata needed access PHG db calculate optimal graph paths: host:port username password database name database type (sqlite postgres) example database configuration can found : SQLite example PostgreSQL example
code: host=localHost user=sqlite password=sqlite DB=/tempFileDir/outputDir/phgTestDB_mapq48.db DBtype=sqlite host=172.17.0.2:5432 user=postgres password=phgP0stgr3s DB=phgdb DBtype=postgres

title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: PHG database configuration file, can proceed following steps. First, can access availabe PHG methods database using path parameter database configuration file: object produce tibble-based data frame contain return method data PHG database. Method IDs descriptions can viewed additional information detailing methods available use building PHG graph object.
code: # Example path location (not run) configPath <- "/home/bm646/Temporary/phg_tests/configSQLite.txt"  phgMethods <- rPHG::showPHGMethods(configFile = configPath) phgMethods ## # A tibble: 7 x 5 ##   method_id method_type type_name        method_name      description        ##       <int>       <int> <chr>            <chr>            <chr>              ## 1         1           1 ANCHOR_HAPLOTYP~ B73Ref_method    Test version for ~ ## 2         2           7 REF_RANGE_GROUP  refRegionGroup   Group consists of~ ## 3         3           7 REF_RANGE_GROUP  refInterRegionG~ Group consists of~ ## 4         4           2 ASSEMBLY_HAPLOT~ mummer4          Assembly aligned ~ ## 5         5           1 ANCHOR_HAPLOTYP~ GATK_PIPELINE    GATK_PIPELINE cre~ ## 6         6           1 ANCHOR_HAPLOTYP~ CONSENSUS        CONSENSUS for cre~ ## 7         7           1 ANCHOR_HAPLOTYP~ consensusTest    consensusTest;det~

title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: Next, can build optimal graph object. single function, called graphBuilder, used subsequent parameters: : configFile: path PHG database configuration file; methods: one prior methods showMethods() function call, specifically, method_name column (see prior output). graph finished building, can inspect object: built, object generated PHGDataSet class. next section, discuss extract specific data object.
code: phgObj <- graphBuilder(     configFile = config_path,     methods = "GATK_PIPELINE" ) phgObj ## class: PHGDataSet  ## dim: 20 6  ## metadata(1): jObj ## assays(1): hapID ## rownames(20): R1 R11 ... R10 R20 ## rowData names(1): refRange_id ## colnames(6): LineA LineA1 ... Ref RefA1 ## colData names(0):

title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: called, PHGDataSet shows similar output SummarizedExperiment RangedSummarizedExperiment class. information commonly used Bioconductor class can found . due PHGDataSet class inheriting methods slot information SummarizedExperiment class. Therefore, can use general accessor methods either SummarizedExperiment S4Vectors packages. examples follows: assay() colData() rowData() rowRanges() metadata() detailed example methods can used PHGDataSet shown :  three main data types can extracted : rowRanges(); rowData(): reference range data colData(); colnames(): taxa (.e. genotype) data assay(): haplotype path ID data matrix form metadata(): access PHG API Java object (advanced use )

title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: Reference range data can accessed via rowRanges() method. use , simply call function prior PHG object (e.g. phgObj prior examples): extracted object GRanges class. another commonly used class “Bioconductor universe” represent genomic intervals. information package can found . Within objecct, get specified reference range information: seqnames: chromosome reference range found ranges: IRanges object contains reference range coordinates strand: strand reference range (+, -, *) refRange_id: given reference range ID within PHG database object, can use additional methods extract specific details start/stop coordinates width reference range: Due wonderful world “inheritance”, can also call function directly SummarizedExperiment objects therefore main PHGDataSet object:
code: # Make a `GRanges` object rr <- SummarizedExperiment::rowRanges(phgObj) rr ## GRanges object with 20 ranges and 1 metadata column: ##       seqnames      ranges strand | refRange_id ##          <Rle>   <IRanges>  <Rle> |    <factor> ##    R1        1      1-3500      * |          R1 ##   R11        1   3501-7500      * |         R11 ##    R2        1  7501-11000      * |          R2 ##   R12        1 11001-15000      * |         R12 ##    R3        1 15001-18500      * |          R3 ##   ...      ...         ...    ... .         ... ##   R18        1 56001-60000      * |         R18 ##    R9        1 60001-63500      * |          R9 ##   R19        1 63501-67500      * |         R19 ##   R10        1 67501-71000      * |         R10 ##   R20        1 71001-75000      * |         R20 ##   ------- ##   seqinfo: 1 sequence from an unspecified genome; no seqlengths GenomicRanges::ranges(rr) IRanges object with 20 ranges and 0 metadata columns:           start       end     width       <integer> <integer> <integer>    R1         1      3500      3500   R11      3501      7500      4000    R2      7501     11000      3500   R12     11001     15000      4000    R3     15001     18500      3500   ...       ...       ...       ...   R18     56001     60000      4000    R9     60001     63500      3500   R19     63501     67500      4000   R10     67501     71000      3500   R20     71001     75000      4000 SummarizedExperiment::ranges(phgObj) IRanges object with 20 ranges and 0 metadata columns:           start       end     width       <integer> <integer> <integer>    R1         1      3500      3500   R11      3501      7500      4000    R2      7501     11000      3500   R12     11001     15000      4000    R3     15001     18500      3500   ...       ...       ...       ...   R18     56001     60000      4000    R9     60001     63500      3500   R19     63501     67500      4000   R10     67501     71000      3500   R20     71001     75000      4000

title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: Additionally, haplotype identifiers can also acessed data object. obtained using assays() method, calling specifically, haplotype ID matrix ($hapID): matrix represents haplotype ID taxa (column names) within PHG database given reference range (row names).

title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: (NOTE: advanced use !) access Java object data PHG API, metadata() method S4Vectors can used. return Java reference object can used defining potential functions methods exist within rPHG package:
code: S4Vectors::metadata(phgObj)$jObj ## [1] "Java-Object{net.maizegenetics.pangenome.api.HaplotypeGraph@f381794}"

title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: Additionally, rPHG currently several summary- visualization-based functions. include ways determine levels similarity reference ranges taxa.

what: Determine numbers of haplotypes per reference range
title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: see total number haplotypes given reference range, function, numHaploPerRange() can used: data returned contain reference range coordinate, IDs, number haplotypes per range (numHaplotypes). data can also passed plotting function, plotNumHaplo() display prior data linear genomic plot. familiar pipe (%>%) operators R via magrittr package, pipeline PHGDataSet visualization can used well:  reference range displayed blue-colored rectangle based physical position within genome y-axis denotes total number unique haplotype IDs per reference range.
code: rPHG::numHaploPerRange(phgObject = phgObj) ## DataFrame with 20 rows and 5 columns ##           names     start       end     width numHaplotypes ##     <character> <integer> <integer> <integer>     <integer> ## 1            R1         1      3500      3500             6 ## 2           R11      3501      7500      4000             6 ## 3            R2      7501     11000      3500             6 ## 4           R12     11001     15000      4000             6 ## 5            R3     15001     18500      3500             6 ## ...         ...       ...       ...       ...           ... ## 16          R18     56001     60000      4000             6 ## 17           R9     60001     63500      3500             6 ## 18          R19     63501     67500      4000             6 ## 19          R10     67501     71000      3500             6 ## 20          R20     71001     75000      4000             6 library(magrittr)  # (1) Non-pipe example haploPlot <- plotNumHaplo(numHaploPerRange(phgObject = phgObj))  # (2) Pipe example. Need to load `magrittr` package first! haploPlot <- phgObj %>%     rPHG::numHaploPerRange() %>%     rPHG::plotNumHaplo()  # Return visualization haploPlot

what: Visualize mutual information between pairs of ranges
title: Getting Started with rPHG
text: plotMutualInfo() plots “amount mutual information” obtained one random variable observing random variable. higher numeric value, related taxa given reference range. function, PHGDataSet reference range IDs form vector (e.g. c("R1", "R2", "R3")) needed. function can also piped using %>% operator magrittr.
code: library(magrittr)  phgObj %>%     rPHG::plotMutualInfo(       refRanges = assays(phgObj)$hapID %>%          rownames()     )
